title: Carbon market gives clearer rules on offsetting - FoodNavigator.com
summary: Amid rising concerns over greenwashing and non-transparent carbon markets, several food companies are steering away from carbon offsets and focusing on reducing emissions within their own operations. Voluntary carbon markets are seeking to instill confidence in the use of carbon offsets by rolling out quality standards for carbon credit projects, including those pertaining to emissions impact, program governance and sustainable development impacts. A significant shift in the voluntary carbon market is encouraging companies to adopt a 'climate contribution' approach, treating carbon credits as a means of addressing global climate issues rather than a compensation for unabated emissions.

title: Two Direct-Air Carbon Removal Projects Set for $1.1B DOE Push - Engineering News-Record
summary: The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) announced that it will provide $1.1 billion in funding to two commercial-scale direct-air carbon removal (DAC) demonstration hubs on the Gulf Coast. The hubs, to be built by Occidental Petroleum Corp. and Battelle, will each have the capacity to remove up to 1 million metric tons of CO2 per year. The projects are part of the DOE's goal to develop a domestic industry to scour carbon emissions from the atmosphere and reach a net-zero emissions economy by 2050.
